gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
  * recompile with O2 or higher to enable loop vectorization and with ffast-math (included in Ofast) to extend vectorization to FP reductions.
 - Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly:
C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<<image_row_maj>>
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)

gain.workaround:
- Reduce the number of division or square root instructions:
  * If denominator is constant over iterations, use reciprocal (replace x/y with x*(1/y)). Check precision impact. This will be done by your compiler with ffast-math or Ofast
 - Check whether you really need double precision. If not, switch to single precision to speedup execution

Performance is limited by execution of divide and square root operations (the divide/square root unit is a bottleneck).

hint.details:
Calling (and then returning from) a function prevents many compiler optimizations (like vectorization), breaks control flow (which reduces pipeline performance) and executes extra instructions to save/restore the registers used inside it, which is very expensive (dozens of cycles). Consider to inline small functions.
 - sqrt@plt: 1 occurrences<<list_path_2_call_1>>

C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<<image_row_maj>>
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
Store and arithmetical SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is probably not vectorized.
Only 25% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 18.00 to 4.50 cycles (4.00x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Reduce the number of division or square root instructions:
  * If denominator is constant over iterations, use reciprocal (replace x/y with x*(1/y)). Check precision impact. This will be done by your compiler with ffast-math or Ofast
 - Check whether you really need double precision. If not, switch to single precision to speedup execution
gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt:
Performance is limited by execution of divide and square root operations (the divide/square root unit is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 18.00 to 6.50 cycles (2.77x speedup).

potential.title: Expensive FP math instructions/calls
potential.txt:
Detected performance impact from expensive FP math instructions/calls.
By removing/reexpressing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 18.00 to 6.50 cycles (2.77x speedup).

hint.details:
Calling (and then returning from) a function prevents many compiler optimizations (like vectorization), breaks control flow (which reduces pipeline performance) and executes extra instructions to save/restore the registers used inside it, which is very expensive (dozens of cycles). Consider to inline small functions.
 - sqrt@plt: 2 occurrences<<list_path_4_call_1>>
hint.title: CALL instructions
hint.txt: Detected function call instructions.

hint.details:
These instructions generate more than one micro-operation and only one of them can be decoded during a cycle and the extra micro-operations increase pressure on execution units.
 - UCOMISD: 2 occurrences<<list_path_4_complex_1>>
hint.title: Complex instructions
hint.txt: Detected COMPLEX INSTRUCTIONS.

hint.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
hint.details:
- Constant unknown stride: 1 occurrence(s)
Non-unit stride (uncontiguous) accesses are not efficiently using data caches
hint.title: Slow data structures access
hint.txt: Detected data structures (typically arrays) that cannot be efficiently read/written

hint.workaround: Avoid mixing data with different types. In particular, check if the type of constants is the same as array elements. Use double instead of single precision only when/where needed by numerical stability and avoid mixing precision. In C/C++, FP constants are double precision by default and must be suffixed by 'f' to make them single precision.
hint.details:
- CVTSD2SS (FP64 to FP32, scalar): 2 occurrences<<list_path_4_cvt_1>>
 - CVTSS2SD (FP32 to FP64, scalar): 4 occurrences<<list_path_4_cvt_2>>
hint.title: Conversion instructions
hint.txt: Detected expensive conversion instructions.

hint.title: Type of elements and instruction set
hint.txt: 6 SSE or AVX instructions are processing arithmetic or math operations on double precision FP elements in scalar mode (one at a time).

hint.title: Matching between your loop (in the source code) and the binary loop
hint.txt:
The binary loop is composed of 4 FP arithmetical operations:
 - 2: addition or subtraction
 - 2: divide
The binary loop is loading 52 bytes (6 double precision FP elements).
The binary loop is storing 28 bytes (3 double precision FP elements).

hint.title: Arithmetic intensity
hint.txt: Arithmetic intensity is 0.05 FP operations per loaded or stored byte.

hint.workaround: Unroll your loop if trip count is significantly higher than target unroll factor and if some data references are common to consecutive iterations. This can be done manually. Or with the unroll (resp. unroll_and_jam) directive on top of the inner (resp. surrounding) loop. You can enforce an unroll factor: #pragma unroll_and_jam N, unroll_and_jam(N), unroll N or unroll(N)
hint.title: Unroll opportunity
hint.txt: Loop is potentially data access bound.

  * recompile with O2 or higher to enable loop vectorization and with ffast-math (included in Ofast) to extend vectorization to FP reductions.

  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly:

for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)

header:
The loop is defined in /home/benabid-guendouzi/Documents/GitHub/AOA-Project5/kernel.c:69-70.
The related source loop is not unrolled or unrolled with no peel/tail loop.
This loop has 4 execution paths.
The presence of multiple execution paths is typically the main/first bottleneck.
Try to simplify control inside loop: ideally, try to remove all conditional expressions, for example by (if applicable):
 - hoisting them (moving them outside the loop)
 - turning them into conditional moves, MIN or MAX

Ex: if (x<0) x=0 => x = (x<0 ? 0 : x) (or MAX(0,x) after defining the corresponding macro)
